content.content: Overview We have been running our PSMs with zero fees for some quarters already (original Signal Request, onchain poll, executive). While that helped to keep the hard peg to USD our stablecoin-ratio has more than doubled from 34% to more than 80% until today. It should be noted that the Maker white paper describes a soft peg rather than a hard peg.   The vast majority of the stablecoins is coming from the USDC-PSM. USDP and especially GUSD have not been equality utilized   We have lowered the Stability Fees to encourage vault holders to mint DAI from crypto collateral, but so far this hasn’t helped much on the stablecoin ratio but instead is just cutting even deeper into our revenues. A softer peg can create arbitrage opportunities for vault holders potentially increasing their utilization. A more detailed explanation on the mechanics of the PSM including some discussion can be found in the pre-SR post I made here.  Proposed Actions  Increase the tin on the USDC-PSM In simple English, this will put a fee on every USDC->DAI swap using our PSM. Arbitraging DAI prices above 1 USD will only happen on the PSM, if the price is above 1 + tin, otherwise the actor will not make a profit. As an example if the tin was 2 bps we would expect the DAI peg to be between $1 and $1,0002  Pros  recreating a freer market on the DAI-price (related post by @michwill from Curve) recreating the arbitrage use case for crypto-vault-users reducing the inflow of new USDC into the protocol Possible decentralization of stablecoin-exposure: might move some stablecoin out of the USDC-PSM into the two other PSMs we are running some (probably not a lot) profits for the protocol Setting the ‘tin’ too high can potentially reduce the inflow into the PSM to zero   Cons  as there is an upwards push on DAI price, we might drift north of 1 DAI = 1 USD (limited through the tin) and by that breaking the promise of an hard peg may hurt gelato-vault-users Setting the ‘tin’ too high can potentially reduce the inflow into the PSM to zero Changes to the PSM mechanics in general can reduce confidence in the protocol, potentially losing users that are expecting mechanics to work a certain way.   Poll: To which level shall we set the tin  Please vote on ALL options you would support in an onchain-poll.     0 - no change 1.0 bps (0.01%) 2.5 bps (0.025%) 5.0 bps (0.05%) 10.0 bps (0.1%) 25.0 bps (0.25%) 50.0 bps (0.5%) Abstain     0 voters      Increase the tout on the USDC-PSM This will put a fee on every DAI->USDC swap using our PSM. Arbitraging DAI prices below 1 USD will only happen on the PSM, if the price is below 1 - tout otherwise the actor will not make a profit. As an example if the tout was 2 bps we would expect the peg to fluctuate between $0,9998 and $1.  Pros  recreating a freer market on the DAI-price (related post by @michwill from Curve) possible decentralization of stablecoin-exposure: might move some stablecoin out of the USDC-PSM into the two other PSMs we are running some (probably not a lot) profits for the protocol   Cons  driving peg of south of 1 DAI = 1 USD (limited through the tout) will not immediately get compensated by USDC outflow from the PSM, as the DAI price needs to be below 1 - tout before this happens will reduce the outflow of USDC from the PSM, slowing down the desired effect of reducing USDC-exposure breaking the promise of an hard peg may hurt gelato-vault-users   Poll: To which level shall we set the tout  Please vote on ALL options you would support in an onchain-poll.     0 - no change 1.0 bps (0.01%) 2.5 bps (0.025%) 5.0 bps (0.05%) 10.0 bps (0.1%) 25.0 bps (0.25%) 50.0 bps (0.5%) Abstain     0 voters      Next steps The polls will run until 2022-09-01T22:00:00Z ; their outcomes will result in two separate onchain polls assuming there is majority for any of the non abstaining options. content.content: brianmcmichael:  Dai was never designed to have a hard peg   This is a bit of a semantical argument but, IMO the best definition for “hard peg” is guaranteed 1:1 redemption; examples of this include fiat backed stablecoins such as USDC, and US retail focused money market funds. I don’t think DAI really falls under this category even with existing 0% PSM fees, because the DAI<>USD peg is maintained through incentives, rather than obligations. If PSM reserves were exhausted due to large withdrawals, DAI would no longer be redeemable and may trade below target price but this wouldn’t lead to a default, because DAI has no obligation to pay holders $1 on demand, only incentives to maintain value close to target price. In this sense I think DAI is still soft pegged as initially described even though our PSM fee strategy has resulted in very close adherence to target price. I don’t think we’re breaking with tradition of maintaining a soft peg as long as we avoid creating strict obligations to counterparties (DAI holders, vault users, RWA borrowers) and remain in the realm of incentives. content.content: (I hope) we can all agree that there is a mismatch in demand for DAI and demand for generating DAI via CDPs. This mismatch in demand can manifest in multiple ways. I will list 2 that we have experience with:  In a system without a PSM, a depeg to the upside, where the magnitude of the depeg represents the magnitude of the demand mismatch In a system with a PSM, a positive balance in the PSM, where the size of that balance represents the magnitude of the demand mismatch.  So 2 questions: Would increasing tin change the demand for DAI? Might lower it because DAI would be less “stable”. This would decrease the demand mismatch, but only by pushing a less user friendly product. Would increasing tin change the demand for DAI generation in CDPs? Realistically, a tin of 50 bps (all else equal) would alter the peg from $1 to $1-$1.005. So users could open debt positions at the upper end of the peg with the hope that when it was time to repay, the price would be closer to the $1 side of the peg, for an overall max favor of 0.5%. I very highly doubt this is a strong enough incentive to change anything. Thus, we can conclude that increasing the tin would not meaningfully change the PSM balance, and any reduction in balance is simply due to DAI demand destruction by shipping a worse product. Not great. When I initially voted, I included all fees options. The arguments in here are extremely in favor of one side though so I slowly changed to 1bp only. But if I were to vote now I’d for sure add the no fees option and would lean toward that. The difference between voting for 0 bps and 1 bp to me would be the revenue that the PSM would be expected to drive at 1 bp.

content.content: I would strongly encourage everyone on the SF team to actually open a vault and consider the user experience of someone with an ETH-A vault. It seems we’re optimizing heavily for mythical RWA borrowers here and neglecting the user experience of our existing customers. Creating and generating Dai from a vault is expensive, a user needs to open the vault, perform the transactions, and then somehow dispose of the Dai. This has a very real cost in ETH terms. By letting the Dai float above peg we’re, at the minimum, letting the market help subsidize that process for these users. Many ETH borrowers are leveraging long on ETH, which is a highly volatile asset, due to that volatility, the difference between 1.00 and 1.005 is marginal to vaultholders, who are expecting to repay later with gains on ETH. If the vaultholder has made an incorrect bet, the 1.005 price tag on Dai is still a bargain if they need to unwind their position and avoid liquidation penalties. Again though, raising the tin doesn’t mean that the price will immediately go up to the cap. If we allow the market to float it will, over time, stabilize and market makers and liquidity providers are able to find yield in those margins. By taking that margin and becoming the trade facility of first resort we’re eating the market, discouraging ecosystem actors from entering and smoothing the price, and taking all of the risk of holding these assets on our books. For a decentralized technology to be resilient we need an ecosystem, and we can do that by leaving a little on the table for external developers to take advantage of. All of these direct-control policies are pushing ecosystem actors elsewhere. One could argue that 13% liquidation penalties are too high, but that window gave DefiSaver an opportunity to enter and develop their project, in my opinion that’s a net good for everyone. Trying to be too efficient when working with decentralized systems is counterproductive.
